parts.text:
You are an expert at creating high-quality Anki flashcards from university lecture slides. Generate concise, atomic cards that test one idea per card. Prefer cloze deletions when appropriate; otherwise use a Basic note with Front/Back fields.

Return ONLY a JSON array. No prose. The array contains objects with these fields: 
- model_name: string (e.g., 'Basic' or 'Cloze')
- fields: object mapping field names to strings (e.g., Front, Back, Text)
- tags: array of strings
- media: optional array of objects with 'filename' and 'data' (base64-encoded image)

Do not include Markdown in field values unless present in the slide.
If including media, choose short, unique filenames (e.g., 'slide-3-diagram.png').

Slide text:
Date 16-09-2013
Knowledge & Agent Systems
Communication

Slide text:
About the course

Slide text:
Learning objectives
› Speech acts
› Protocols
› Auctions
› Dialogue
▪Argumentation
▪Language development
3

Slide text:
Speech acts
› Speech act theory emphasises the
pragmatics of language.
› The syntax and semantics of language 
do not determine pragmatics.
Example: 
A: Can you pass me the salt, please?
B: Yes, I can.

Slide text:
Speech acts
› Speech act theory goes back to the book How 
to Do Things with Words by John L. Austin 
(1962).
› Austin noted that what we say can change the 
world, in a way similar to physical actions.
▪Declaring war
▪‘I now pronounce you man and wife’
▪Deciding a legal case (by a judge)

Slide text:
Aspects of a speech act
› Locution: the physical act of saying 
something.
› Illocution: the associated act of showing an 
intention or goal (stating, questioning, 
commanding, promising, ...).
› Perlocution: the resulting action or event 
(the change of a belief, the answer, the 
action, the obligation, ...).

Slide text:
Types of speech act (John Searle)
›
Representatives:
aimed at informing, e.g., ‘I made tea’
›
Directives:
aimed at the hearer doing something, e.g., ‘Please make 
the tea’ 
›
Commissives:
aimed at a commitment of the speaker, e.g., ‘I promise 
to make tea’ 
›
Expressives:
aimed at expressing a mental state, e.g., ‘I like this tea!’
›
Declaratives:
aimed at a change of the world, e.g., `I declare you man 
and wife'

Slide text:
Components of speech acts
A performative verb:
request, inform, promise, … 
Propositional content:
“the door is closed”
By the use of performatives, the same 
propositional content can serve different 
roles.

Slide text:
Components of speech acts
› “Please close the door”
▪
performative = request
▪
propositional content = “the door is closed”
› “The door is closed!”
▪
performative = inform
▪
propositional content = “the door is closed”
›
“Is the door closed?”
▪
performative = inquire
▪
propositional content = “the door is closed”

Slide text:
Defining speech acts using logic
› Recall how we defined actions using logic in 
terms of preconditions and postconditions. 
› In 1979, Cohen & Perrault defined speech 
acts using pre- and postconditions.
› Key difference: a speech act is not defined by 
an actual outcome, but by an intention or 
goal.

Slide text:
Request
Pre-condition: 
▪
speaker believes hearer is capable of performing an
action;
▪
speaker believes that hearer believes that hearer is 
capable of performing the action;
▪
speaker believes that speaker wants the action to be 
performed. 
Rational effect
▪
hearer believes that speaker believes that speaker 
wants the action to be performed.

Slide text:
request(s, h, a)
precondition:
s believes (h can do a)
s believes (h believes (h can do a))
s believes (s want a)
postcondition:
h believes (s believes (s want a))

Slide text:
Agent Communication Language (ACL)
(inform
    :sender agent1
    :receiver hpl-auction-server
    :content
      (price (bid good02) 150)
    :in-reply-to round-4
    :reply-with bid04
    :language sl
    :ontology hpl-auction
)
Begin message structure
Communicative act type
Message parameter
ACL message
Message content expression
Parameter expression

Slide text:
FIPA performatives
Foundation for Intelligent Physical Agents (FIPA)

Slide text:
Learning objectives
› Speech acts
› Protocols
› Auctions
› Dialogue
▪Argumentation
▪Language development
16

Slide text:
The Contract Net Protocol
The Contract Net Protocol (Smith 1980) is a 
formalized protocol for task sharing with five 
phases:
Recognition: The initiator recognizes its problem
Announcement: The initiator announces its 
problem to participants
Bidding: Participants make a proposal (a bid)
Awarding: The initiator chooses one or more 
proposals.
Expediting: The awarded proposals are executed.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contract_Net_Protocol

Slide text:
Learning objectives
› Speech acts
› Protocols
› Auctions
› Dialogue
▪Argumentation
▪Language development
20

Slide text:
Auctions
› Goal: allocate goods.
› An auction takes place between an 
auctioneer agent and bidder agents.
› Typically the auctioneer aims to maximize the 
price and bidders to minimize the price.
21

Slide text:
Auctions and resource allocation
› Auctions are tools to efficiently allocate scarce 
resources to agents
› Efficient here means: allocating the resources 
to the agents that value them the most
› Sometimes: an auction reveals information 
about bidders
22

Slide text:
Auction parameters
›Goods can have
▪private value
▪public/common 
value
▪correlated value
›Winner pays
▪first price
▪second price
›Bids may be
▪open cry
▪sealed bid
›Bidding may be
▪one shot
▪ascending
▪descending
23

Slide text:
English Auctions
› Commonly known auction type:
▪
first price
▪
open cry
▪
ascending
› Dominant strategy is to successively bid a 
small amount more than the current highest 
bid until it reaches the agent’s valuation, then 
withdraw
24

Slide text:
Dutch Auctions
› Dutch auctions are examples of open-cry 
descending auctions:
– auctioneer starts by offering good at 
artificially high value
– auctioneer lowers offer price until some 
agent makes a bid equal to the current offer 
price
– the good is then allocated to the agent that 
made the offer
25

Slide text:
Broeker Veiling (Broek op Langedijk)
26

Slide text:
27

Slide text:
First-Price Sealed-Bid Auctions
› First-price sealed-bid auctions are one-shot 
auctions:
–
there is a single round
–
bidders submit a sealed bid for the good
–
good is allocated to agent that made highest bid
–
winner pays price of highest bid
› Winner could have won by bidding just a bit 
more than the second highest bid. Therefore 
there is an incentive to bid less than true 
valuation.
28

Slide text:
Vickrey Auctions
› Vickrey auctions are:
▪second-price
▪sealed-bid
› Good is awarded to the agent that made the 
highest bid; at the price of the second highest 
bid
› Bidding to your true valuation is dominant 
strategy in Vickrey auctions
› Hence by its design the Vickrey auction 
reveals information about bidders

Slide text:
‘Proof’ (part 1)
› Let x be an agent’s true valuation. Assume 
the agent bids y with y > x.
▪Case 1: the agent wins.
-
The agent has to pay the second highest bid z.
-
When x < z < y, the agent pays more than his 
true valuation x.
-
When z < x, the agent would have paid the same 
in case of bidding x.
▪Case 2: the agent loses.
-
In case the agent had bid x, he would still have 
lost.
› Conclusion: it is useless to bid more than x
30

Slide text:
‘Proof’ (part 2)
› Let x be an agent’s true valuation. Assume 
the agent bids y with y < x.
▪Case 1: the agent wins.
-
The agent has to pay the second highest bid z.
-
Since z < x, the agent would have paid the same 
in case of bidding x.
▪Case 2: the agent loses.
-
If y < z < x, the agent would have won by bidding 
x.
-
If x < z, the agent would still have lost in case of 
bidding x. 
› Conclusion: it is useless to bid less than x
31

Slide text:
Four main types of auctions
› English auctions
› Dutch auctions
› First-price sealed-bid auctions
› Vickrey auctions
32

Slide text:
Issues with auctions
›
Shills (English auctions)
Among the bidders there can be secret associates of 
the seller.
›
Bidder collusion (all four auction types)
Bidders can collaborate to decrease the prices paid
›
Lying auctioneer (the two sealed bid auctions)
The auctioneer can lie about the content of sealed 
bids.
›
Winner’s curse (all, but reduced in Vickrey auctions)
The winner of an auction assigns a higher value to a 
good than the others. So the winner could have paid 
less ...
33

Slide text:
Auction parameters
›Goods can have
private value
public/common value
correlated value
›Winner pays
first price
second price
›Bids may be
open cry
sealed bid
›Bidding may be
one shot
ascending
descending
34

Slide text:
Auctions in practice
› Mobile phone bandwidth auctions
▪
'There was a great deal of caterwauling as telecom 
executives sought to blame [...] game theorists who 
supposedly made them pay more for their licenses 
than they were worth. But who but an idiot would bid 
more for something than they thought it was worth?' 
(Binmore 2007 on early 2000s 3G auctions)
› Online auctions: e.g., proxy bidding at eBay
› Adword auctions: e.g., Google's auctions 
taking place every time a search is submitted 
($3 bln in revenue, 2004) 
$95 bln in 2017
35

Slide text:
Learning objectives
› Speech acts
› Protocols
› Auctions
› Dialogue
▪Argumentation
▪Language development
37

Slide text:
Dialogue
› Communication often takes the shape of a 
dialogue.
› In argumentation theory, protocols for 
various types of argumentative dialogue have 
been proposed.
› Dialogue has been used to study language 
development
38

Slide text:
Argumentation dialogue
Walton and Krabbe Commitment in Dialogue 1995

Slide text:
Walton and Krabbe Commitment in Dialogue 1995
Argumentation dialogue

Slide text:
Speech acts in argumentation dialogue
› Claim (make an assertion)
› Argue so (give a reason)
› Challenge why ? (ask for a reason)
› Retract (withdraw a claim)
41

Slide text:
Talking heads (Luc Steels and his team)
Dialogue-based language development
42

Slide text:
Talking heads (Luc Steels and his team)
Robot cameras ("inhabited" by software agents traveling 
over the internet between Paris to Tokyo, Brussels, 
Antwerp) & real scene: variability and noise
Guessing game
1. S chooses a topic
2. S tries to find a meaning in a discrimination tree
3. S looks up a signal for this meaning
4. H 'points' at the object it thinks or guesses is meant by S 
(pointing is transmitted info of where camera looks)
5. S sends success or failure message, possibly with a hint 
by pointing
43

Slide text:
Learning objectives

› Dialogue

44
